channel.title: Knowledge-systems on Oli Wilkins
channel.description: Recent content in Knowledge-systems on Oli Wilkins

item.title: Indefinite Article
item.description: An indefinite article refers to non-specific nouns. You could say: I need a pen. I want an orange. In both cases, this does not refer to a specific pen or orange. Any will do. References
item.content:
An indefinite article refers to non-specific nouns. You could say:

I need a pen. I want an orange.

In both cases, this does not refer to a specific pen or orange. Any will do.

References

item.title: Conjugation
item.description: A verb can be conjugated with reference to the number, person, mood or tense. Examples: I teach English We teach English You teach English He teaches English She teaches English They teach English References
item.content:
A verb can be conjugated with reference to the number, person, mood or tense. Examples:

  • I teach English
  • We teach English
  • You teach English
  • He teaches English
  • She teaches English
  • They teach English

References

item.title: Citation Form
item.description: In Bulgarian, citation form is used to refer to a verb or to look it up in a dictionary. It is different from the infinitive in a grammatical sense. For example: “to be” is “съм” Съм is used for the citation form and for “I am” References
item.content:
In Bulgarian, citation form is used to refer to a verb or to look it up in a dictionary. It is different from the infinitive in a grammatical sense.

For example:

  • “to be” is “съм”
  • Съм is used for the citation form and for “I am”

References

item.title: Adverb
item.description: An adverb is a word that modifies a verb (he sings loudly), an adjective (very tall), another adverb or even a whole sentence (fortunately, I had brought an umbrella). References
item.content:
An adverb is a word that modifies a verb (he sings loudly), an adjective (very tall), another adverb or even a whole sentence (fortunately, I had brought an umbrella).

References

item.title: Infinitive
item.description: Infinitives are a special form of verbs that can be used as a noun, adjective or adverb. They are usually made by adding the word to before the base verb. They are useful when discussion actions without actually doing the action: I want to go home. I like to write in English. Example: I need to win. Today, we win. In the first sentence, the infinitive form of the verb win is used.
item.content:
Infinitives are a special form of verbs that can be used as a noun, adjective or adverb. They are usually made by adding the word to before the base verb. They are useful when discussion actions without actually doing the action:

  • I want to go home.
  • I like to write in English.

Example:

  • I need to win.
  • Today, we win.

In the first sentence, the infinitive form of the verb win is used. The main verb of the sentence is actually “need”. The second sentence uses the standard form of win as an actionable verb. In he first sentence with the infinitive, the action of “winning” is not actually done. The sentence simply discusses the idea of winning. The second sentence however, describes the action of winning.

References

item.title: Verb
item.description: A verb is a word that describes what the subject of the sentence is doing. They can indicate (physical or mental) actions, occurrences and states of being. Jeff builds a house. Anita is thinking about horses. True love exists. References
item.content:
A verb is a word that describes what the subject of the sentence is doing. They can indicate (physical or mental) actions, occurrences and states of being.

Jeff builds a house. Anita is thinking about horses. True love exists.

References

item.description: In Bulgarian verbs are conjugated according to the subject (I, you, …) and the tense (past, present, …). This conjugation is applied to the ending of the verb. References
item.content:
In Bulgarian verbs are conjugated according to the subject (I, you, …) and the tense (past, present, …). This conjugation is applied to the ending of the verb.

References

item.title: 20230129213905-A
item.description: Verbs do not have an infinitive form. When referring to a verb, use the first person conjugation of that verb. Here are examples Bulgarian the citation form “to be”. Example: “to be” is “съм” Съм is used for the citation form and for “I am” Two conjugations of “съм”: I am - Аз съм he/she/it is - той/тя/то е Examples: “Той е мъж” - He is a man “Тя е жена” - She is a woman “Това е куче” - This is a dog Since the conjugations are unique to each subject, the pronoun can be left out:
item.content:
Verbs do not have an infinitive form. When referring to a verb, use the first person conjugation of that verb. Here are examples Bulgarian the citation form “to be”.

Example:

  • “to be” is “съм”
  • Съм is used for the citation form and for “I am”

Two conjugations of “съм”:

  • I am - Аз съм
  • he/she/it is - той/тя/то е

Examples:

  • “Той е мъж” - He is a man
  • “Тя е жена” - She is a woman
  • “Това е куче” - This is a dog

Since the conjugations are unique to each subject, the pronoun can be left out:

  • Instead of “аз съм мъж” (I am a man), you can say “мъж съм”

References

item.title: 20230129213905-A1
item.content:
It is a rule that you cannot start a sentence with a present form of the verb съм (“to be”). When you omit the subject personal Pronoun, the verb has to move into the second position:

  • “Аз съм мъж” or “Мъж съм” – I am a man

It is incorrect to say: “съм мъж”

References

item.description: In English there are 2 types of articles: Definite Indefinite There is no definite article in Bulgarian: “жена” and “куче” are used alone to refer to “a woman” and “a dog”: “Ту е жена” - She is a woman “Аз имам куче” - I have a dog References
item.content:
In English there are 2 types of articles:

  • Definite
  • Indefinite There is no definite article in Bulgarian:
  • “жена” and “куче” are used alone to refer to “a woman” and “a dog”:
    • “Ту е жена” - She is a woman
    • “Аз имам куче” - I have a dog

References

item.title: Adjective
item.description: Adjectives are words that describe the qualities or states of being of nouns. Examples: Rob wore a beautiful hat. Furry dogs may overhead in the summertime. My cake should have sixteen candles. The scariest villain of all time is Darth Vader. References
item.content:
Adjectives are words that describe the qualities or states of being of nouns. Examples:

Rob wore a beautiful hat. Furry dogs may overhead in the summertime. My cake should have sixteen candles. The scariest villain of all time is Darth Vader.

References

item.title: Noun
item.description: A noun is a word that refers to a person, place, thing or idea. References
item.content:
A noun is a word that refers to a person, place, thing or idea.

References

item.title: Pronoun
item.description: A pronoun is a word that stands in a for noun, often to avoid the need to repeat the same noun over and over. Use this when your reader/listener already knows which nouns you are referring to. Example: I have a dog. He’s brown and white. References
item.content:
A pronoun is a word that stands in a for noun, often to avoid the need to repeat the same noun over and over. Use this when your reader/listener already knows which nouns you are referring to.

Example:

  • I have a dog. He’s brown and white.

References

item.title: Definite Article
item.description: A definite article refers to a specific noun. You could say: >The man’s dog barked at me. >I lent my sister the book when I finished reading it. >I didn’t go to the the party. References
item.content:
A definite article refers to a specific noun. You could say: >The man’s dog barked at me. >I lent my sister the book when I finished reading it. >I didn’t go to the the party.

References
